Using fwapgr

Source: vignettes/fwapgr.Rmd
fwapgr.Rmd

fwapgr is an R client for the BC Freshwater Atlas PostgreSQL database web API. It gets and filters data from the BC Freshwater Atlas into R!

In this article, we will create a basic map of the Yakoun River watershed in Haida Gwaii, BC, primarily using fwapgr’s workhorse function: fwa_collection. We can get started by looking at all available tables and which columns are in a specific table.

fwapgr::fwa_meta_collections()
#> # A tibble: 41 x 4
#>    collection_id           description                extent$crs $bbox  links   
#>    <chr>                   <chr>                      <chr>      <list> <list>  
#>  1 hydrosheds.hybas_lev12… Data for table hydrosheds… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#>  2 usgs.wbdhu12            Data for table usgs.wbdhu… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#>  3 whse_basemapping.fwa_a… Data for table whse_basem… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#>  4 whse_basemapping.fwa_a… Data for table whse_basem… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#>  5 whse_basemapping.fwa_b… Data for table whse_basem… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#>  6 whse_basemapping.fwa_b… Data for table whse_basem… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#>  7 whse_basemapping.fwa_b… Data for table whse_basem… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#>  8 whse_basemapping.fwa_c… Data for table whse_basem… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#>  9 whse_basemapping.fwa_g… Data for table whse_basem… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#> 10 whse_basemapping.fwa_i… Data for table whse_basem… EPSG:3005  <int … <df[,4]…
#> # … with 31 more rows
fwapgr::fwa_meta_properties('whse_basemapping.fwa_stream_networks_sp')
#> # A tibble: 27 x 3
#>    name                     type   description
#>    <chr>                    <chr>  <chr>      
#>  1 linear_feature_id        number ""         
#>  2 watershed_group_id       number ""

#>  5 watershed_key            number ""         
#>  6 fwa_watershed_code       string ""         
#>  7 local_watershed_code     string ""         
#>  8 watershed_group_code     string ""         
#>  9 downstream_route_measure number ""         
#> 10 length_metre             number ""         
#> # … with 17 more rows

fwa_collection allows us to retrieve data from any available table in the database and filter for desired values on any column. To get a linestring feature of the Yakoun river, we could use the ‘fwa_stream_networks_sp’ or ‘fwa_named_streams’ table and filter by gnis_name column.

fwapgr::fwa_collection("whse_basemapping.fwa_stream_networks_sp", filter = list(gnis_name = "Yakoun River"))

Let’s also get the Yakoun River watershed using the “fwa_named_watersheds_poly” table.

wshed <- fwapgr::fwa_collection("whse_basemapping.fwa_named_watersheds_poly", filter = list(gnis_name = "Yakoun River"))

Next, let’s get all the lakes that are within the Yakoun river watershed. We can use the bbox argument for this and the ‘fwa_lakes_poly’ table.

bbox <- sf::st_bbox(wshed)
lakes <- fwapgr::fwa_collection("whse_basemapping.fwa_lakes_poly", bbox = bbox)

Finally, lets get all streams within the watershed bounds with stream_order greater than 1. order streams.

streams <- fwapgr::fwa_collection("whse_basemapping.fwa_stream_networks_sp", bbox = bbox)
streams <- streams[streams$stream_order > 2,]

To make the map look a little prettier, we can clip the stream and lake layers to the watershed polygon.

streams <- sf::st_intersection(streams, wshed)
lakes <- sf::st_intersection(lakes, wshed)

Developed by Sebastian Dalgarno, Poisson Consulting.
